itinerary.activity: Welcome and introduce the exhibit. Begin by greeting the students and briefly explaining the purpose of the tour. Introduce the exhibit 'Objectifying China' as a way to explore Chinese art, history, and symbolism through porcelain objects. Highlight that the tour will focus on Ming and Qing dynasty ceramics, connecting art to world history.

Overview of the Ming Dynasty and symbolism. Discuss the significance of the Ming dynasty in world history, emphasizing its contributions to art and trade. Introduce Wucai (‘five-colour') porcelains as a key innovation of the late Ming and Qing dynasties. Explain how colors and designs on porcelain often carried symbolic meanings, such as dragons representing power or phoenixes symbolizing renewal.

Hands-on engagement: Spot the symbolism. Guide students to examine specific porcelain pieces in the exhibit. Ask them to identify colors, patterns, and symbols on the objects. Encourage them to guess what the symbols might mean based on their knowledge of world history or Chinese culture. Share fun facts, such as how blue-and-white porcelain reached the Medicis in Florence during the Ming dynasty, showing global connections.

Explore polychrome techniques and imperial marks. Explain how Wucai porcelains were created using polychrome techniques and why they became popular. Show examples of imperial marks on porcelain pieces and discuss how these marks indicated objects made for the court or related institutions. Highlight the craftsmanship and cultural significance of these items.

Interactive comparison: Ming vs. Qing porcelain. Present examples of blue-and-white porcelain from the Ming dynasty and compare them to Wucai porcelains from the Qing dynasty. Ask students to identify differences in style, color, and symbolism. Discuss how these changes reflect shifts in culture, technology, and trade over time.

Wrap-up and conclusion. Summarize the key points covered during the tour, emphasizing the global impact of Chinese porcelain and its role in connecting art, history, and symbolism. Invite students to share their favorite object or fact from the tour. Thank them for their participation and encourage them to explore more about Chinese art and history in their studies.
